title: Tourist tries to steal roof tile from Pompeii to buy iPhone
text:
Tourist tries to steal roof tile from Pompeii to buy iPhone Last updated 08:44, August 16 2015 CIRO DE LUCA/REUTERS 
The ancient archaeological site of Pompeii. 
A teenager has been arrested for attempting to steal a roof tile from the ancient city of Pompeii so he could buy himself an iPhone. 
The 16-year-old from Holland, was spotted by an American tourist when he tried to conceal the priceless relic in his backpack. 
Police were called and the teen was charged with attempted theft and handed over to his mother. 
Photo: Reuters 
The teen had hoped to sell the tile on eBay and buy the latest iPhone, but experts say he would have been left disappointed. 
"A simple terracotta tile actually has a very low value, we don't even trade them," Carole Elena, a dealer in Roman artefacts, told The Loca l. 
"Being a tile from Pompeii, its provenance might have given it some extra value, but I'd say it's worth a maximum of â‚¬400 (NZ$679)... but obviously items like this are priceless in terms of their historical value." 
The tile has been returned to staff at Pompeii but it might be a while before it is returned to its proper place as neither the Dutch, or American tourist could remember where the tile originally was. 
One of Italy's most popular attractions, Pompeii was preserved under ash from a volcanic eruption in 79 AD and rediscovered in the 18th century. It has become a symbol for decades of mismanagement of Italy's cultural sites after a series of collapses that have brought an international outcry.
